Award.AwardTitle: 2017 Regenerative Medicine Workshop at Hilton Head, SC

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1655376
Guldberg

NSF has made an award to support travel costs and registration fees for 7 workshop speakers and registration fees for 19 trainees and 5 young faculty members who will attend the three-day Regenerative Medicine Workshop at Hilton Head being held March 1-4, 2017, on Hilton Head Island, SC. The workshop, part of a series that began in 1996, brings together national and international regenerative medicine experts from a variety of engineering and scientific disciplines in a small conference setting to effectively convey knowledge, stimulate new ideas critical to advancing the development of regenerative medicine applications and therapies and promote research collaborations. This year's workshop will focus on the theme of cellular models in regenerative medicine. Conference session topics will include: Cellular therapies for liver disease; Cell-based models for human retinal degenerative diseases; Genome sequencing and epigenomic regulation; Regeneration of pancreatic cells for treating diabetes; Nanoscale approaches for cell regeneration; and Combating muscle degeneration diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 21st Annual Regenerative Medicine Workshop at Hilton Head was held on March 1-4, 2017 at the Harbour Town Inn and Conference Center in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina. The Hilton Head Workshop is an annual three day workshop series that has been organized and led by regenerative medicine leaders from Georgia Tech’s Petit Institute for Bioengineering and Bioscience since 1997. The goal of the workshop is to share new research discoveries with the regenerative medicine community, to foster research collaborations, and to promote academic-industry partnerships specific to the development of new biomedical technologies. The number of workshop attendees is intentionally kept small to facilitate interaction with attendance typically around 160 participants.  Registered workshop participants for this year’s workshop totaled 162 comprised of academic professionals (41%), pre-doctoral and postdoctoral trainees (44%), industry representatives (14%), and government officials (1%). Additionally, seven international registrants participated in the workshop. 

This year’s conference theme was “Synergizing Science, Engineering, and Clinical Translation” and focused on the translation of research into innovative bioengineering technologies.  The conference organizing partners were the Georgia Tech-Emory Regenerative Engineering and Medicine Center, Mayo Clinic, the University of Wisconsin-Madison and the University of Pittsburgh/McGowan Institute for Regenerative Medicine. 

The workshop format was a single plenary session that promotes interaction among a diverse body of participants.  Session topics included: immunoengineering; gene therapy; biomaterials for orthopedic applications; biomimetic materials; synthetic biomaterials; stem cell morphogens; and controlling stem cell fate.  There were a total of 39 lectures, 63 posters, and a debate titled “MSCs are not Stem Cells.”

The program keynote lecturers included: David Gamm, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health; Ronald Germain, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease/National Institutes of Health; Charles Gersbach, Duke University; Michel Levin, Tufts University; Molly Stevens, Imperial College of London; Clive Svendsen, Cedars-Sinai; Amy Wagers, Harvard Medical School; Jennifer West, Duke University.

Pre-doctoral and post-doctoral trainees had the opportunity to participate in podium talks, poster sessions, and the highly popular “rapid-fire” talks that allow for a brief five-minute presentation followed by facilitated discussion. In addition, trainees had the opportunity to connect with national and international regenerative medicine leaders throughout the workshop, and a special trainee networking session was held to connect graduate students and postdoctoral fellows

 


Last Modified: 06/05/2017
Modified by: Robert E Guldberg
